titleStmt.title: Metabolism and Metabolomics of Eukaryotes Living Under Extreme Conditions

affiliation.orgName: Institut fü r Biochemie und Biologie

analytic.title: Metabolism and Metabolomics of Eukaryotes Living Under Extreme Conditions

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Treatises on extremophiles are frequently focused on organisms belonging to the Archaea and Eubacteria kingdoms. However, a significant number of eukaryotes, both unicellular and multicellular, have evolved to live and thrive in extreme environments. Although less is known about eukaryotic life in extreme environments in comparison to prokaryotic extremophiles, advances in genomics and in comprehensive, high-throughput metabolic profiling techniques have provided new insight into the metabolic adaptations of eukaryotes living under extreme conditions. In this review, we will provide an overview of extremophilic life forms with emphasis on eukaryotes and we will compare metabolic adaptations in different eukaryotic extremophiles to identify generalities and specializations in adaptation to life under extreme conditions. Special emphasis will be devoted to the thermoacidophilic unicellular red alga Galdieria sulphuraria (Cyanidiaceae) as one example of a eukaryotic extremophile.

div.head: I. Introduction
div.p: The definition of extremophily is anthropocentric, defining those environments as extreme that are hostile to human life. True extremophiles ''love'' extreme conditions; that is, they live and thrive in extreme conditions and they require these conditions for optimal growth. In contrast, life forms that merely tolerate and survive extreme conditions, but grow optimally under nonextreme conditions, are not usually classified as extremophiles. However, in a broader sense, we also consider organisms as extremophiles that are able to withstand extreme conditions.

Extremophiles are grouped according to their optimal growth environments: alkalophiles show optimal growth at pH values above 10, whereas acidophiles require pH values of lower than 4 for growth; barophiles or piezophilic species require high hydrostatic pressure, endoliths live inside rocks, halophiles require high ionic strength of the growth medium (at least 0.2 M salt), and thermophiles require high temperatures, whereas psychrophiles are adapted to life at very low temperatures. Combinations of the above are frequent, for example, many thermoacidophiles are known that live at high temperature and at low pH (Cavicchioli, 2002;Rothschild and Mancinelli, 2001); see also http://www.babs.unsw.edu.au/research/ehm/lab_cavicchioli_ extremo.html and http://www.astrobiology.com/extreme.

Although hyperthermophiles (i.e., optimal growth at temperatures > C) are restricted to the Archaea, other extremophiles such as thermophiles, acidophiles, psychrophiles, and halophiles can be found in all three domains of life (i.e., in Eubacteria, Archaea, and Eukaryota). The highest growth temperature (113 C) was observed for the archaebacterium Pyrolobus fumarii (Blochl et al., 1997) and growth temperatures above 85 C are frequently observed for archaebacteria. Pyrodictium occultum and P. fumarii are both able to survive 1 h of autoclaving (121 C, 2 bar) (Blochl et al., 1997;Stetter, 1999). The upper temperature limit of eubacteria is around 90 C, whereas the upper temperature limit of eukaryotic life is currently estimated at approximately C (Rothschild and Mancinelli, 2001). While prokaryotes are the undisputed champions at the high end of the temperature spectrum of life, eukaryotic extremophiles are equivalent to their prokaryotic peers with respect to pH, salinity, and desiccation tolerance. At the low end of the temperature spectrum, eukaryotes clearly outcompete prokaryotes. For example, the Himalayan midge is still active at temperatures of À20 C (Kohshima, 1984). Also, prokaryotic cyanobacteria are not found below pH values of 4 (Brock, 1973), while eukaryotic microalga of the rhodophytes and chlorophytes are the principal photosynthetic organisms in these environments.

div.head: II. Eukaryotic Extremophiles
div.p: Due to space constraints, a comprehensive review of all reported eukaryotic extremophiles is not possible in this review; we will rather provide selected examples from diVerent clades of the eukaryotic domain of life.

div.head: A. Algae and Plants
div.p: Photosynthetic prokaryotes such as the cyanobacteria are completely absent from acidic waters with pH values below 4 (Brock, 1973). Instead, thermoacidophilic photosynthetic unicellular red algae of the Cyanidiales (Doemel and Brock, 1970;Donachie et al., 2002;Rothschild and Mancinelli, 2001) and members of the green algae are the main photosynthetic organisms found in these ecological niches. The occurrence of green algae is usually restricted to temperatures below 42 C, whereas the Cyanidiales have an upper temperature limit of 56 C.

At the other end of the temperature scale, psychrophilic algae occur in ice-dominated habitats such as snowfields, sea ice, glaciers, permafrost, and ice clouds. They must persist at very low temperatures and survive multiple freeze-thaw cycles. To maintain metabolic activity at temperatures below 0 C, enzymes of psychrophiles have evolved several adaptations such as a destabilized active site, allowing for more enzymatic flexibility (D'Amico et al., 2002;Georlette et al., 2004;Hoyoux et al., 2004). Green algae (Chlorosarcinopsis, Pleurastrum, Palmellopsis, Bracterococcus) as well as brown algae (Laminariales) are well represented among the psychrophiles (Raven et al., 2002;Vincent et al., 2004). To avoid UV-induced cell damage, caused by high solar radiation, chlorophytes often associate with cyanobacteria inside microbial mats and are thereby coprotected by cyanobacterial UV-screening compounds (Vincent et al., 2004). Various algae belonging to the diatoms, dinoflagellates, chlorophytes, euglenophytes, chrysophytes, and prasinophytes are found at high salinity and low temperature, for example, the sea ice algae that live in liquid brine found in cracks and pockets of arctic sea ice. The salinity tolerance of marine algae has been reviewed by Kirst (1989), therefore marine algae are not further considered in this review. In addition, due to space constraints, we restrict our review to selected members of the green and red algae, and land plants.

div.head: Green Algae
div.p: Dunaliella spec. (Dunaliella parva and Dunaliella viridis) are halophilic green algae that are found, for example, in the Dead Sea where they are the only primary producers (Oren, 1999). The total salt concentration at the surface of the Dead Sea is currently in the range of 340 g/liter, with ionic concentrations (in mol/liter) of 1.9 (Mg 2þ ), 1.6 (Na þ ), 0.4 (Ca 2þ ), and 6.4 (Cl À ) (Oren, 1999). While these extreme salt concentrations are not permissive to growth of Dunaliella, slight dilution of the upper water layers by rain floods, for example, is followed by massive blooms of Dunaliella to cell densities around 1 Â 10 4 cells ml À1 (Oren and Shilo, 1982). However, it is also possible that not salt concentration but nutrient availability limits the growth of Dunaliella in the Dead Sea (Oren et al., 1995), with phosphate being the limiting nutrient (Oren, 1983;Oren and Shilo, 1985).

Acidophilic green algae are found in the genera Dunaliella (i.e., Dunaliella acidophila) (Pick, 1998) and Chlamydomonas. Chlamydomonas acidophila populates extremely acidic lakes (GerloV-Elias et al., 2005a,b) and also the heavy-metal laden, highly acidic Rio Tinto river (Messerli et al., 2005). A thermoacidophilic Chlamydomonas strain (Chlamydomonas pitschmannii Ettl) has been isolated from a hot spring in the Campi Flegrei Caldera near Naples in Italy (Pollio et al., 2005).

div.head: Red Algae
div.p: Cyanidiaceae (Cyanidiales) are a small group of evolutionary ancient, diverged, extremophilic red microalgae. They are extremophiles in many diVerent ways: Cyanidiaceae are obligate acidophiles, living at pH 0.05-3. To date, only a single Cyanidium-like strain has been reported from a nonacidic cave habitat (HoVmann, 1994). In addition, they are facultative mesothermophiles, with optimal growth temperatures around 42 C and an upper temperature limit of 56 C (Doemel and Brock, 1970;Deluca and Taddei, 1976;Gross et al., 2002). However, habitats with nonelevated temperatures are also colonized (Gross and Gross, 2001;Gross et al., 2002). Cyanidiaceae thrive in pure CO 2 (Seckbach et al., 1970) and are resistant to high concentrations of heavy metals (Albertano and Pinto, 1986;Nagasaka et al., 2004) and high amounts of salt (Gross et al., 2002; R. J. Horst and A. P. M. Weber, unpublished observations).

The Cyanidiaceae have always been regarded as a very conserved group (Seckbach and Fredrick, 1980). However, earlier hypotheses on their bridging function between the prokaryotic blue-green and the eukaryotic algae do not hold up against our current understanding of evolution. Based on molecular clock estimates, Cyanidiales are probably more than 1.5 billion years old and thus likely some of oldest extant eukaryotic organisms. According to Yoon et al. (2002Yoon et al. ( , 2004 the Cyanidiaceae form a sister group to the other rhodophytes and are located at the basis of secondary endosymbiosis. This event gave rise to the large group of Chromalveolates, comprising the Chromista (cryptophytes, haptophytes, and stramenopiles) and the Alveolates (ciliates, dinoflagellates, and parasitic Apicomplexa) (Archibald and Keeling, 2002;Bhattacharya et al., 2004). In addition to molecular data, the phylogenetic position of the Cyanidiaceae is also supported by detailed studies on the evolution of starch metabolism in Apicomplexa, rhodophytes, and chlorophytes (Coppin et al., 2005;Patron and Keeling, 2005).

Following current taxonomy, six species are classified as Cyanidiaceae: Cyanidium caldarium, Cyanidioschyzon merolae, Galdieria partita, Galdieria daedala, Galdieria maxima, and Galdieria sulphuraria (Albertano et al., 2000;Ciniglia et al., 2004). A clear diVerentiation between the genera Galdieria, Cyanidium, and Cyanidioschyzon is diYcult and the systematics of the Cyanidiaceae has long been a matter of debate (Deluca and Taddei, 1976;Merola et al., 1981;Seckbach, 1991). Cyanidioschyzon is quite easily distinguished by its oval shape, the lack of a cell wall, and binary fission as mode of replication. DiVerentiating between Galdieria and Cyanidium is more diYcult due to a very similar morphology. Biochemical and physiological features like the utilization of nitrate, carbon heterotrophy, and the occurrence of linolenic acid have been proposed as markers (Boenzi et al., 1977;Merola et al., 1981;Nagashima et al., 1986). However, at a closer look, only the latter two criteria can be considered reliable (Gross, 1999).

div.head: Plants
div.p: Naturally occurring salt-tolerant species (halophytes) are frequently found in near-seashore environments and salt marshes, for example, Beta maritima, a close relative of the sugar beet, or Salicornia bigelovii, a halophyte that was suggested for use as an oilseed crop that can be irrigated with sea water (Glenn et al., 1991). The salt cress Thellungiella halophila, a salt-tolerant brassicacean species that naturally occurs in Eastern China and that is closely related to Arabidopsis, has emerged as a model system to study tolerance to salt and a variety of other abiotic stressors such as cold and desiccation (Bressan et al., 2001;Inan et al., 2004;Wong et al., 2006). It tolerates seawater strength salt solutions (Inan et al., 2004), temperatures of À18 C, and severe water loss (Wong et al., 2006). Other plant model systems used in analyzing plant salt tolerance are the inducible crassulacean-acid metabolism (CAM) plant Mesembryanthemum crystallinum (common ice plant) (Bohnert and Cushman, 2000) and a salt-tolerant poplar species (Populus euphratica; Ottow et al., 2005). However, in contrast to algae, salt-tolerant land plants in most cases cannot be considered halophilic organisms sensu stricto, they rather tolerate relatively high salt concentrations but frequently show highest growth rates at low or moderate salinity.

While most seed plants produce desiccation-tolerant seeds, their vegetative tissues are usually sensitive to desiccation. Exceptions to this rule are the so-called ''resurrection plants.'' These plants are able to survive complete desiccation of their vegetative tissues for long time periods. Upon rehydration, resurrection plants resume growth and complete their life cycle. Multiple cycles of dehydration and rehydration are commonly survived (Alpert, 2000). Resurrection plants occur in the monocotyledonous and dicotyledonous phyla of the angiosperms, but have not been reported in gymnosperms (Bartels, 2005;Bartels and Mattar, 2002;Bartels et al., 2004). Probably the best-studied angiosperm model system for desiccation tolerance is Craterostigma plantagineum (Bartels, 2005;Bartels and Salamini, 2001;Ingram and Bartels, 1996). In contrast to angiosperms, desiccation tolerance is quite common in mosses (bryophytes), algae, and lichens, whereas it is less frequently observed in ferns (pteridophytes) (Alpert, 2000;Oliver et al., 2005). Desiccation tolerance was likely the first strategy that enabled plants to settle on land; other mechanisms and structures allowing plants to grow in dry air such as cuticulae, stomata, and water transport structures evolved later. The evolution of complex morphological and physiological adaptations to life on land was accompanied by the loss of primary desiccation tolerance in vegetative structures, whereas it was retained in seeds, pollen, and spores. Likely, the evolution of vegetative (secondary) desiccation tolerance in seed plants represents independent evolutionary events, probably in response to the selective pressure associated with dwelling in extremely arid habitats (Oliver et al., 2005).

div.head: B. Metazoa
div.p: While humans thrive in an amazing variety of extreme conditions, ranging from arid deserts to permafrost tundra and even in extraterrestrial and innercity habitats, they are not generally considered extremophiles since human settlement in extreme environments is mostly achieved by cultural and technological advances and not metabolic adaptation (maybe with the exception of alcohol tolerance). However, a number of metazoa have evolved to live in extreme environments such as high temperature and pressure, high salinity, and desiccation, and we will introduce several representative examples in the following paragraphs.

Hydrothermal vents at the Atlantic and Pacific Ocean seafloors emit superheated, mineral-rich water that provides the basis of life for chemolithoautotrophic bacterial communities (sulfide oxidizers), which are the primary producers in these deep-sea ecosystems (Inagaki et al., 2002;Ishii and Marumo, 2002;Juniper et al., 1995;Summit and Baross, 2001). The microbial communities provide organic material to higher trophic levels, such zooplankton, mollusks, worms, and other heterotrophic organisms in these dark, high-pressure environments. While most of these organisms dwell a safe distance from the superheated water, reports demonstrate the presence of thermophilic worms living in tubes that are relatively close to the heat source (McMullin et al., 2000). Based on temperature measurements in occupied tubes, it has been reported that the alvinellid Alvinella pompejana is able to tolerate sustained temperatures of 60 C (Cary et al., 1998), which is close to the upper temperature limit of eukaryotic life (Rothschild and Mancinelli, 2001). However, measurements under controlled chemical and temperature conditions in pressurized chambers indicated that the temperature limit for metazoan life at hydrothermal vents should be considered to be above 45 C, but less than 60 C (Lee, 2003). An EST-sequencing program for Alvinella pompejana is currently in progress at the DOE Joint Genome Institute (http://www.jgi.doe. gov/sequencing/why/CSP2005/Apompejana.html).

Tardigrades (water bears) are small, bilateral multicellular animals that belong to the Ecdysozoa, which also includes the arthropods and the nematodes (Halanych, 2004). These animals can tolerate extreme desiccation by entering a stress-resistant ''tun''-state. In this state, they reportedly survive temperatures close to absolute zero at the low end and 150 C at the high end of the temperature spectrum (Copley, 1999). It is essential for survival that desiccation and tun formation occur slowly; trehalose accumulation is believed to be crucial during this process (Somme, 1996). Entering the cryptobiotic stage is thought to be important for wind dispersal in the natural environment (Nelson, 2002;Nkem et al., 2006).

The brine shrimp Artemia dwells in hypersaline environments, such as natural solar salterns and forms encysted embryos (cysts) that are able to withstand thermal extremes and repeated desiccation-rehydration cycles (Clegg, 2005). Similar to tardigrades, accumulation of trehalose is critical to the survival of cysts during anhydrobiosis (Clegg, 2005) and small heat shock proteins play an important role in this process (Clegg et al., 1999).

div.head: C. Fungi
div.p: Among the fungi, ''black yeast'' is the most resistant. ''Black yeast'' is an arbitrary term for melanized fungi of the Chaetothyriales or Dothideales (Sterflinger et al., 1999). Their cell wall is incrusted with the pigment melanin, protecting them against UV light, cytotoxic radicals, enzymatic attack, high temperatures, desiccation, and high concentrations of heavy metal (Butler and Day, 1998;Caesar-Tonthat et al., 1995;Wheeler and Bell, 1988). Melanin is also linked to virulence in some human pathogenic and phytopathogenic fungi (Langfelder et al., 2003). The black yeast Hortaea (Sothideales, Ascomycota) is composed of species that are extreme halophiles (H. werneckii; Petrovic et al., 2002) as well as extreme acidophiles (H. acidophila; Holker et al., 2004). H. acidophila has been isolated from a suspension at pH 0.6 containing humic and fulvic acids. Lignite was used as the sole carbon source. The fungus is not obligate acidophilic, but also grows at neutral pH-changing from single cell to filamentous morphology. The upper temperature limit of cells is 30 C (Holker et al., 2004). While H. acidophila does not tolerate 5% NaCl, H. werneckii thrives in media with up to 30% salt and is therefore used as a eukaryotic model system for salt tolerance (Petrovic et al., 2002). The natural habitat of H. werneckii is hypersaline waters such as solar salterns (Gunde-Cimerman et al., 2000). The genus Hortaea is thus composed of the most salt-and acid-tolerant eukaryotic microorganisms on earth.

div.head: III. Metabolic Analysis and Adaptations of Extremophiles
div.p: A. Metabolic Analysis

div.head: Definition of Metabolomics
div.p: Metabolomics is a relatively new term; a search of the ISI Web of Science database using the keyword ''metabolomics'' shows the first hit in 2000 (Fiehn et al., 2000a), some 10 papers in 2001, and as of February 2006 a total of 412 records plus 22 additional nonredundant citations listed in MEDLINE. The first paper listed under the keyword metabolomics (Fiehn et al., 2000a) has been cited 261 times as of February 2006, and a search of Google for ''metabolomics'' returns 455,000 hits, emphasizing the dynamic development of the field. In contrast to targeted metabolite analysis or metabolic fingerprinting (metabonomics), the term metabolomics describes the comprehensive qualitative and quantitative analysis of all small molecules (metabolites) present in biological material at the time of sampling (Fiehn, 2002;Sumner et al., 2003), although this ambitious goal has not yet been achieved in reality. Together with other ''omics'' approaches such as genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, interactomics, and fluxomics, metabolomics constitutes one of the cornerstones of systems biology, which is the quest to gain a holistic understanding of how complex biological systems work by simultaneously monitoring all processes and interactions happening within the system, with the eventual goal of developing predictive mathematical models of the system that deliver testable hypotheses for in vitro and in vivo studies (Kitano, 2002a,b).

Because many excellent reviews comprehensively cover all aspects of metabolomics (Bender, 2005;Fernie et al., 2004;Fiehn, 2002;Glinski and Weckwerth, 2006;Halket et al., 2005;Kopka et al., 2004;Sumner et al., 2003;Weckwerth, 2003), we will emphasize and briefly summarize only the key concepts.

div.head: Methods Used in Metabolomics
div.p: Plants produce a dazzling array of metabolites--their total number is estimated to be around 200,000 (Weckwerth, 2003), and a single plant may contain several thousand primary and secondary metabolites. The number of diVerent metabolites and their enormous chemical complexity hamper a comprehensive simultaneous quantitative and qualitative analysis of all small molecules. This ideal goal of metabolomics is therefore not feasible using a single analytic technology. Consequently, a combination of technologies is applied in parallel and the complexity of samples is reduced prior to separation and detection.

Currently, the most commonly used technologies used in metabolomics are nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (Nicholson et al., 1999(Nicholson et al., , 2002Raamsdonk et al., 2001) and chromatographic (gas chromatography, liquid chromatography) or electrophoretic (capillary electrophoresis) separation methods coupled to mass spectrometry (MS). While NMR provides good chemical specificity and throughput, it is several orders of magnitude less sensitive than MS and thus more suitable for metabolic fingerprinting (metabonomics) than for comprehensive metabolomic analysis (Rochfort, 2005;Sumner et al., 2003).

Gas chromatography (GC) in combination with mass spectrometry (GC-MS) and electron-impact (EI) ionization provides very high separation power and sensitivity. However, GC can separate only volatile compounds. Hence nonvolatile metabolites must be rendered volatile by chemical derivatization, thereby increasing time and the number of handling steps in sample preparation. In addition, derivatization causes a higher complexity of mass spectra, thus hampering compound identification. The development of GC coupled to time-of-flight mass spectrometry (TOF-MS; Sacks, 2000, 2001) has increased sensitivity, mass accuracy, and dynamic range in comparison to scanning-type mass spectrometers such as quadrupoles and ion traps. These new instruments allow the acquisition of several hundred full-range mass spectra per second (quadrupole instruments: 1-6 spectra per second), thus permitting shorter separation times, better mass spectral deconvolution, and more reliable quantification. Further improvements in speed and resolution are achieved by two-dimensional GC (GC Â GC) TOF-MS (Dalluge et al., 2002;Hope et al., 2005).

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) in combination with MS and electrospray ionization (ESI;Fenn et al., 1990;Yamashita and Fenn, 1984a,b) is increasingly used in metabolomics. Liquid chromatography (LC) allows the chromatographic separation of nonvolatile compounds without prior derivatization, thereby permitting the analysis of organic diphosphates and larger metabolites, such as oligosaccharides, and secondary metabolites, which cannot be analyzed by GC-MS. LC can easily be coupled to photodiode array or UV detectors in parallel to the mass detector. This additional information can be used for compound identification (Sumner et al., 2003). In contrast to GC-MS, comprehensive libraries of mass spectra and retention indices (Wagner et al., 2003) are not available for LC-MS and ionization techniques such as ESI are more variable than EI applied in GC-MS, thus complicating the reliable and reproducible identification of metabolites. Nevertheless, LC-MS spectra can be simpler to interpret than GC-MS spectra because metabolites do not have to be derivatized and thus give, within the limitations of the mass detector, access to the accurate mass of the parent ion, although solvent adducts may cause problems. LC in combination with tandem mass spectrometry (such as MS-MS, using triplequadrupole or QTOF instruments) can be used for the elucidation of the structure of unknown organic compounds by fragmentation of molecules followed by analysis of the fragmentation pattern. Briefly, the parent (precursor) ion of interest is selected based on its molecular mass in a first quadrupole, then it is fragmented in a second quadrupole cell by collision of the parent ions with gas atoms, for example (collision-induced decay, CID), and the daughter (product) ion mass spectra (CID spectra) are subsequently analyzed in a third quadrupole. The main advantage of this approach versus in-source fragmentation is that the specific fragment pattern (spectrum) of a particular precursor ion is obtained, which can be used for structural elucidation. In summary, GC-MS and LC-MS are complementary techniques that, if applied in combination, enable the comprehensive qualitative and quantitative analysis of small molecules.

div.head: Data Mining
div.p: As is characteristic for all ''omics'' types of technologies, metabolomics generates huge datasets and it is not trivial extracting the important variables and the underlying structures from these data; basically, it comes down to the analysis of highly dimensional datasets that consist of a large number of rows (e.g., metabolites) and columns (e.g., diVerent sampling conditions). This is frequently approached by exploratory data analysis, using clustering analysis, projections methods, self-organizing maps, or genetic algorithms. The point is to identify those components (i.e., metabolites) that are the key to understanding the changes in the system in response to genetic modification or environmental perturbation, for example. Moreover, the desire is to integrate across multiple omics levels (i.e., transcriptomics and metabolomics), with the eventual goal to understand living organisms at the systems level. A treatise of this is beyond the scope of this review and the reader is referred to several studies on these topics (Fernie et al., 2004;Goodacre, 2005;Ideker et al., 2001a,b;Kopka et al., 2004;Urbanczyk-Wochniak et al., 2003).

div.head: B. Halophilic Algae and Plants
div.p: In the following we will review the metabolic adaptations that enable eukaryotic extremophiles to cope with high salinity, acid, and desiccation. Special emphasis will be given to protists and plants.

Higher plants and nonmotile algae cannot evade high salt concentrations in their environment and have therefore developed multiple adaptations to salt stress. In general, plants respond to salt stress by inhibition of photosynthesis and stimulation of photorespiration. This is the result of a CO 2 limitation at high salinity (Wingler et al., 2000). The same applies to aquatic systems (Sass and Benyaakov, 1977). While salt tolerance in most plants (e.g., Pisum sativum) is limited (Speer and Kaiser, 1991), other photosynthetic eukaryotes can cope with very high salt concentrations. The green alga Dunaliella sp. grows optimally at a salt concentration between 6 and 9% NaCl, and still tolerates 30% salt (Borowitzka and Brown, 1974). A proteomics approach has revealed several adaptations to salt stress in the halophile D. salina (Liska et al., 2004). Among them are upregulation of photosynthesis and starch mobilization as well as increased synthesis of Na þ redox transporters and glycerol. The CO 2 limitation in D. salina is overcome by the induction of multiple plasma membrane carbonic anhydrases. While salinity tolerance in Dunaliella is at the upper end of the plant spectrum, higher plants tolerate much less salt. The halophilic salt cress Thellungiella halophila is resistant to 3% NaCl as well as low humidity and freezing (Inan et al., 2004).
Halotolerance/halophily can be the result of many diVerent mechanisms, and often, a single plant uses multiple strategies (Benamotz and Avron, 1983;Hasegawa et al., 2000;Kirst, 1989).

div.head: Inorganic Compounds
div.p: The accumulation of inorganic ions is an energy-eYcient and fast way to adjust the osmotic potential of the cell to the surrounding medium. In marine algae, in particular Na þ and Cl À seem to be involved in this process, while K þ accumulates under salt stress (Kirst, 1989). The uptake of Na þ into the plant cell is not yet fully understood, but it is assumed that Na þ is taken up by K þ transporters that lose their specificity at high external Na þ concentrations (Amtmann and Sanders, 1996;Mahmood and Kaiser, 2003). The involuntary uptake of Na þ leads to a depolarization of the plasma membrane and Cl À can passively flow into the cell through anion channels (Hedrich, 1994). Due to the potentially inhibitory eVect of Na þ and Cl À on enzyme activities, an accumulation to high concentrations in the cytoplasm is not a suitable strategy. Instead, inorganic ions are often sequestered in the central vacuole where they serve as osmotically active compounds (Glenn et al., 1999;Hasegawa et al., 2000). This is, in contrast to the influx of ions into the cytoplasm, an energy-consuming process, as the ions are transported against a concentration gradient (Blumwald and Poole, 1985). Organisms that do not accumulate Na þ and Cl À under salt stress must possess an export system for these ions. Horie and Schroeder (2004) have reviewed plant Na þ transporters that might be involved in this eZux system. The role of K þ in adaptation to salt stress in plants is ambiguous. While K þ accumulates in salt-stressed marine algae (Kirst, 1989), its concentration does not change in salt-adapted tobacco cells (Binzel et al., 1988). The salt-sensitive pea plant (Speer and Kaiser, 1991) as well as the salt-tolerant kallar grass (Mahmood and Kaiser, 2003) have lower K þ concentrations when they are salt stressed than under nonstress conditions. The discrepancy in the role of K þ might be the result of diVerent strategies for adaptation of plants to osmotic and to ionic stress.

div.head: Compatible Solutes
div.p: Inorganic ions can accumulate only to a certain level in enzymatically active compartments before they inhibit enzyme activities, yet the osmotic potential of all compartments needs to be adjusted in response to osmotic stress. This is achieved by the accumulation of compatible solutes (Brown and Simpson, 1972). In contrast to inorganic ions, compatible solutes do not inhibit enzyme activities, even at very high concentrations (Benamotz and Avron, 1972) and are, therefore, better suited as osmolytes in enzymatically active compartments. Compatible solutes are highly soluble in aqueous solutions, accumulate proportionally to the external salt concentration (Hasegawa et al., 2000), and act as osmoprotectants. They form water-like structures around proteins, thereby protecting them from inorganic ions that could cause the proteins to denature (Schobert, 1977). The synthesis of compatible solutes is an energyconsuming process: 56 mol of ATP is needed for the biosynthesis of 1 mol of a C 6 sugar. In comparison, the uptake of 1 mol NaCl requires only 0.54 mol ATP (Marschner, 1995).

So far, several metabolites have been described that act as compatible solutes in stressed plants. The amino acid proline seems to be the most widely distributed one (Delauney and Verma, 1993). It accumulates up to 319-fold in tomato cell-suspension cultures stressed with 25% polyethylene glycol (PEG; Rhodes et al., 1986), and up to 8-fold in Arabidopsis thaliana plants stressed with 120 M NaCl (Chiang and Dandekar, 1995). Betaines, especially glycine betaine, are found as compatible solutes in bacteria, animals, higher plants, and algae (Hasegawa et al., 2000). Glycine betaine is mainly localized in the chloroplasts (Marschner, 1995) and can stabilize the structure and function of the oxygen-evolving photosystem II in the presence of molar concentrations of MgCl or NaCl (Papageorgiou and Murata, 1995). The tertiary sulfonium compound dimethylsulfoniopropionate (DMSP) has received special attention because it is the precursor of dimethylsulfide, the major source of sulfur in the earth's atmosphere (Charlson et al., 1987). DMSP acts as a compatible solute in many marine algae, such as Tetraselmis subcordiformis (Dickson and Kirst, 1986). Also, sugar alcohols are often used as compatible solutes. Glycerol accumulates in NaCl-stressed Chlamydomonas sp. cells (Okamoto and Suzuki, 1964) and Dunaliella sp. can build up and maintain an intracellular glycerol concentration of up to 7 M (Benamotz and Avron, 1973;Borowitzka and Brown, 1974) when grown in 5.5 M NaCl. Mannitol is accumlated in response to salt stress in many brown and some red algae. For Ecklonia radiata and Caloglossa leprieurii, mannitol concentrations of nearly 0.2 M have been measured (Kirst and Bisson, 1979;Mostaert et al., 1995). The sugar floridoside (2-O-glycerol-a-D-galactopyranoside) is the main product of photosynthesis in rhodophytes and often accumulates as compatible solute (Kirst and Bisson, 1979). It has also been discussed as a carbon precursor for the synthesis of cell wall polysaccharides (Li et al., 2002). In Porphyra purpurea, floridoside concentrations reach up to 0.6 M when the alga is stressed with concentrated seawater (Reed et al., 1980). Galdieria sulphuraria can tolerate up to at least 10% NaCl under experimental as well as under natural conditions (Gross et al., 2002).

To analyze the metabolic response of G. sulphuraria to high external salt concentrations, we conducted metabolic profiling of cells grown heterotrophically on glucose in the absence or presence of NaCl, respectively. The polar phases of methanol:chloroform:water extracts of cells grown under salt stress (1. 25 M NaCl) and control cells (0 M NaCl), respectively, were methoxiaminated and silylated as described by Fiehn and colleagues (2000b) and analyzed on an Agilent Technologies 6890N Network GC-System equipped with an Agilent 5973 inert mass selective detector and an Agilent 7683 Series injector to determine which compounds accumulate under salt stress. For the identification of compounds by mass spectrometry, we used the Q_MSRI_ID metabolite mass spectral library of the MPI in Golm, Germany (http:// csbdb.mpimp-golm.mpg.de/csbdb/dload/dl_msri.html), in addition to a selfmade mass spectra library consisting of floridoside, trehalose, glycine-betaine, L-proline, sorbitol, mannitol, glycerol, and myoinositol.

The main compounds showing significant increases (relative to the standard (arabinose, Ara)) under salt stress are proline (peak a, Fig. 1), citric acid (peak b, Fig. 1), and floridoside (peak c, Fig. 1). In addition, a minor increase of norvaline was found in high salt, whereas glutamate was detectable only in extracts of control cells. Increase of floridoside was independently confirmed by a coupled enzymatic test (detected as glycerol after acid hydrolysis) and by high-pH anion-exchange chromatography (HPAEC). Proline was detected by a spectrophotometric test (ninhydrin reaction). HPAEC also revealed the presence of trehalose in extracts of Galdieria cells grown in high salt (R. J. Horst and A. P. M. Weber, unpublished observations). In addition to the metabolites mentioned previously, several other compounds, such as sucrose, trehalose, sorbitol, and methylated inositols, have been shown to accumulate in salt-stressed plants (Hasegawa et al., 2000). Trehalose also accumulates in tardigrades (Somme, 1996) and in crustacean embryos (Clegg, 2005) during desiccation and when entering cryptobiosis (Clegg, 2001).

Resurrection plants also display distinct changes in metabolism during desiccation and rehydration cycles. Fully hydrated leaves of Craterostigma plantagineum contain high amounts of the unusual C sugar octulose. During desiccation, octulose is degraded whereas sucrose accumulates to levels similar to that of octulose in fully hydrated leaves. This process is reversed during rehydration (i.e., sucrose declines and octulose accumulates again) (Bianchi et al., 1991). A detailed study of small molecules in leaves and calli of C. plantagineum showed that desiccated and ABA-treated calli showed increases in fatty acids and colneleic acid, an inhibitor of lipoxygenase, whereas glucose and fructose disappeared and octulose was converted to glucose (Bianchi et al., 1992).

To the best of our knowledge, the first study applying comprehensive metabolic analysis in combination with full-genome transcript profiling to a eukaryotic extremophile was conducted on the extremophilic Arabidopsis cousin Thellungiella halophila (Gong et al., 2005). The metabolite analysis revealed that Thellungiella contains higher levels of metabolite than Arabidopsis both in the absence and presence of salt stress. This was due to significantly higher contents of hexoses, disaccharides, and complex sugars of an unidentified nature. In addition, Thellungiella contained higher amounts of sugar alcohols, in particular, inositol and galactinol (Gong et al., 2005). Proline accumulated in response to salt stress in both Arabidopsis and Thellungiella, but increases were more pronounced in Thellungiella. In addition, Thellungiella contained much higher levels of glutamate and aspartate, as well as higher levels of the organic acids malate and citrate (Gong et al., 2005).

In general, compatible solutes can be divided into four groups: (1) polyols, such as glycerol, mannitol, and sorbitol, (2) glycosides, such as trehalose and floridoside, and (3) amino acids, such as proline and glutamic acid. The fourth group includes all other organic compounds that accumulate in response to salinity (Benamotz and Avron, 1983). It has been shown in vitro that some solutes are better suited for osmoprotection than others. Proline and glycerol are most eVective in the protection of proteins while disaccharides are the least eVective (Engelbrecht et al., 1999;Kirst, 1989). Many organisms accumulate more than just one of the compounds mentioned previously when exposed to salt stress. And as plant cells contain multiple compartments, it has been suggested that diVerent solutes accumulate in diVerent compartments (Setter and Greenway, 1983).

div.head: C. Acidophilic Algae
div.p: In an acidic environment, photosynthetic cells have to cope with several environmental factors that directly or indirectly relate to low pH. Some of them are the maintenance of a steep proton gradient across the plasmalemma, a low CO availability for photosynthesis, and a high solubility of toxic ions.

Despite a highly acidic environment, most acidophilic algae, such as G. sulphuraria or Chlamydomonas acidophila, maintain a neutral cytosol (Colman et al., 2002;Enami et al., 1986). Enzymes of G. sulphuraria exhibit a pH optimum in the neutral range and show no in vitro activity at low pH (Gross et al., 1997;Oesterhelt et al., 1996). The proton gradient across the plasma membrane reaches ratios of up to 1:10 -1:10 6 . It can be built up and maintained either by reducing the influx of protons and/or actively exporting protons. During vegetative growth, cells have to communicate with their environment and take up nutrients--often via H þ symport. Unwanted uptake of H þ is therefore inevitable and subsequent, energy-consuming export of protons is most likely. However, when deprived of all external energy sources, G. sulphuraria can survive several months and resumes cell growth immediately after resupply of energy. Cells must, thus, be able to limit or actually completely shut oV the influx of protons (Gross, 2000). This mechanism of self-sealing as a response to energy deprivation is not yet understood. It is most likely related to spore formation, though spores have not yet been reported for the Cyanidiaceae. The induction of an extracellular peroxidase at the onset of the stationary phase is a good indication for cell wall modifications similar to lignification or suberine formation in higher plants (Vogelbein, 2003). However, a detailed characterization of these putative spores has yet to be carried out.

In extremophiles belonging to the plant kingdom, the cell wall usually represents the main barrier against a very harsh environment (Enami et al., 1975). In addition to the cell wall, many red algae produce extracellular polysaccharides (e.g., galactans) that provide additional protection. However, these are absent in the Cyanidiaceae, making them ideal candidates for enzymatic studies, which are often hampered by mucilage in other red algae.

Unfortunately, our present understanding of the cell wall composition of Galdieria and Cyanidium is very limited. Cell walls are rich in protein (50-55%) and contain very small amounts of polysaccharides (12-14%). Diaminopimelic acid, muramic acid, and amino sugars are absent (Bailey and Staehelin, 1968).

Another problem at low pH is the high solubility of toxic ions, such as heavy metals (Chuan et al., 1996). Acidophilic organisms, therefore, have to be tolerant of many toxic metal ions (Nagasaka et al., 2002(Nagasaka et al., , 2004. Most likely, this tolerance can be attributed to active secretion of ions (Nagasaka et al., 2002;Yoshimura et al., 1999).

Photosynthesis of acidophiles--as also of halophiles--is hampered by a low CO 2 availability. At low pH, almost all dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) is present in the form of CO . In contrast, at alkaline or neutral pH, HCO

À is the main DIC source, and CO 2 is often enriched via extracellular carbonic anhydrase as part of a carbon-concentrating mechanism (CCM) (Raven, 1997). Accordingly, only nonacidophilic Dunaliella species express an extracellular carbonic anhydrase while Dunaliella acidophila does not have an active CCM (Geib et al., 1996). However, autotrophic acidophiles often make use of a passive CCM: CO is immediately converted into HCO À after uptake into the neutral cytosol. This passive CCM increases intracellular CO 2 concentrations about 10-to 15-fold (Gehl and Colman, 1985). To overcome the DIC limitation of acidic habitats, photosynthesis is often supplemented by uptake of organic carbon. The number of aquatic mixotrophs in acidic habitats is therefore high (Stibor and Sommer, 2003;Tittel et al., 2003). In G. sulphuraria, photoassimilation is boosted by an unusually high CO 2 aYnity of ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RubisCO) (Uemura et al., 1997). This eYcient carboxylation suppresses photorespiration in Cyanidiaceae and contributes to overcoming the CO limitation of photosynthesis.

div.head: D. Endolithic Algae
div.p: Endolithic habitats form protective niches in extremely adverse environments, such as the Ross Desert in the Antarctic, which can be colonized by lichens, bacteria, algae, and fungi (Friedmann and Meyer, 1987;Friedmann et al., 1993). However, they impose extreme conditions on their inmates (e.g., by shutting them oV from light).

div.head: Autotrophy of Endolithic Algae
div.p: The light availability in endolithic habitats depends on the make-up of the rock that is colonized and the depth of the cells. Sandstone and gypsum-like material are among the most frequent habitats (Gross et al., 1998;Hughes and Lawley, 2003), but also ice (Vincent et al., 2004) and skeletons of scleractinians are colonized (Fine et al., 2005). While the first two endolithic habitats impose light limitation on cells, the latter are associated with high solar radiation. Under normal conditions in coral reefs, less than 5% of the photosynthetically active radiation reaches green endolithic algae due to light absorbance by the endosymbiotic dinoflagellates and the carbonate skeleton. However, due to coral bleaching microendoliths may be exposed to high levels of thermal and solar stress (Fine et al., 2005). Also endolithic ice-algae are exposed to high solar radiation and often use UV-screening compounds for shielding (Vincent et al., 2004).

A diVerent scenario is present in light-limited endolithic communities, such as the endolithic cell mats of the Cyanidiaceae (Gross and Oesterhelt, 1999;Gross et al., 1998). Restricted to low pH, G. sulphuraria, C. caldarium, and C. meolae mainly colonize endolithic habitats, where they are protected from desiccation but have access to elevated CO 2 levels, as compared to acidic aquatic habitats that are DIC limited (see previous discussion). Cell mats are often found several centimeters inside the stone, where light availability lies well below the light compensation point for photosynthesis of G. sulphuraria (Oesterhelt et al., in preparation). The exact light compensation points of C. caldarium and C. merolae have not yet been determined and it is not yet known how these obligate autotrophs cope with light limitation inside the stone. Galdieria is the only facultative heterotroph among the Cyanidiaceae and can therefore survive periods of light limitation.

div.head: Heterotrophy of Endolithic Algae
div.p: Among eukaryotic algae, the heterotrophic capacities of Galdieria (Cyanidiaceae) are unique. Cells can use carbohydrates (disaccharides, hexoses, pentoses, and deoxysugars) and sugar alcohols (hexitols, pentiols, tetriols, and triols) as well as organic acids and amino acids as sources for organic carbon, and they often use the D-configuration of sugars as well as the L-configuration (Gross and Schnarrenberger, 1995b;Rigano et al., 1976Rigano et al., , 1977. Uptake of substrates is accomplished by a complex system of at least diVerent H þ symporters (Oesterhelt et al., 1999). This transport machinery is regulated by diVerent mechanisms. The minority of transporters is constitutively expressed, while others are induced in a substrate-specific manner. Minute amounts of a metabolically suitable substrate are suYcient for induction. Glucose as well as other hexoses and hexitols appear to be the preferred substrates. Their presence in the medium leads to a repression of transporters for less abundant compounds (e.g., fucose) (Oesterhelt and Gross, 2002;Oesterhelt et al., 1999). The presence of the protein kinase Snf1 and its regulatory subunit Snf4 as well as the general repressor protein Tup1 in Galdieria suggests a signaling pathway similar to that of glucose repression in yeast (C. Oesterhelt, unpublished observations). Enzymes, which are required for the introduction of the wide variety of substrates into the central cell metabolism, appear to be constitutively expressed in Galdieria. Hexoses are phosphorylated by multiple hexose kinases (W. Gross, unpublished observations;Heilmann et al., 1997b); pentoses are converted to pentiols by an aldose reductase (Gross et al., 1997); hexitols are converted to hexoses and pentiols to pentuloses by multiple polyol dehydrogenases and subsequently phosphorylated (Stein et al., 1997).

Galdieria does not use only the ''common'' substrates (e.g., glucose, fructose) for heterotrophic growth but also some compounds that higher plants cannot metabolize. Two examples are mannose and galactose. Both are often toxic due to the accumulation of phosphorylated sugars. In Galdieria, mannose-6-phosphate is metabolized by a phosphomannose isomerase as well as a mutase (Gross et al., 1997;Heilmann et al., 1997a;Oesterhelt et al., 1996), both working in concert to introduce the phosphorylated sugar into the main pathway of carbohydrate metabolism. Galactose-1-phosphate is metabolized to UDP-galactose via the Leloir pathway and then epimerized to UDP-glucose by UDP-galactose 4-epimerase (Gross and Schnarrenberger, 1995a). These are just some examples for the spectacular metabolic versatility of Galdieria. There are still several substrates for which the metabolism has not yet been unraveled in detail (e.g., dulcitol, which is initially converted to tagatose) (W. Gross, unpublished observations).

In addition to carbohydrates, Galdieria can also grow heterotrophically on organic acids and amino acids (Rigano et al., 1976(Rigano et al., , 1977. Due to the requirement of carbon skeletons and energy for nitrogen assimilation, carbon and nitrogen metabolisms are tightly linked. Nitrogen is mainly assimilated in the light when photosynthesis is active. In the dark, storage carbon has to be broken down to meet the demand for carbon precursors and energy. The nitrogen source of choice is ammonium, however, most Cyanidiaceae can use nitrate as well (Rigano and Violante, 1972). Ammonium is taken up by an ammonium transport system (Fuggi et al., 1981). Nitrate uptake occurs via two specific permeases--a low-aYnity and a high-aYnity system. The low-aYnity system is constitutively expressed and independent of external pH; the high-aYnity system is induced under nitrogen starvation and works only at low external pH (Fuggi, 1985;Fuggi et al., 1984). Nitrite is taken up by passive diVusion of HNO 2 across the cell membrane or by the high-aYnity nitrate transporter (Fuggi, 1993). Ammonium is assimilated through a glutamine synthetase/glutamate synthase pathway and nitrate via nitrate reductase (Rigano, 1971;Rigano and Violante, 1973). This enzyme was amongst the first studied in Cyanidium. It uses NADH as well as NADPH and is inactivated in the presence of ammonium (Rigano et al., 1974). Some Cyanidium isolates from Naples (Italy) are unable to use nitrate (Deluca and Taddei, 1972). Apparently, these strains lack glutamate dehydrogenase while they have high alanine dehydrogenase and L-alanine aminotransferase activities, suggesting that cells incorporate ammonia through reductive amination of pyruvate and may form glutamate from 2-ketoglutarate by a transamination reaction with alanine . Glutamate synthase activity has been reported to be absent from both nitrate-assimilating and nitrate-nonassimilating strains, while glutamine synthetase could be detected . Interestingly, glutamate synthase is encoded on the plastid genomes of all Cyanidiales studied (i.e., C. merolae [Ohta et al., 2003], C. caldarium [Glöckner et al., 2000], and G. sulphuraria [A. Minoda and A. Weber, unpublished observations]), whereas it is encoded on the nuclear genome of all sequenced green plant genomes. Neither the nuclear genome of C. merolae (Matsuzaki et al., 2004) nor that of G. sulphuraria (Barbier et al., 2005;Weber et al., 2004a) encodes a glutamate synthase.

div.head: IV. Genomics and Metabolomics Working Hand in Hand
div.p: Genomics is a useful tool to analyze the genetic potential of an organism and its phylogenetic background, and comparative genomics can identify specific adaptations. However, genomics does not provide an answer to metabolic activity of putative proteins or the structure of metabolic pathways. To find answers to these questions, we need to complement genomics with, for example, proteomics and metabolomics.

Comparative genomics (i.e., the comparison of genomes of diVerent organisms) is a powerful tool to unravel the molecular foundations of observable traits and phenotypes that cannot easily be deduced from the analysis of individual genome sequences. The underlying idea is that conserved regions of DNA between two species often encode common features of the organisms, while diVerent traits will appear as diVerences in the genetic makeup between the two species (Hardison, 2003). Similar genomes, such as those of Galdieria and Cyanidioschyzon, are particularly useful for elucidating key diVerences that account for structural and metabolic diVerences in these organisms.

Using the genome sequence of C. merolae (Matsuzaki et al., 2004) and a G. sulphuraria genomic dataset consisting of an EST collection (Weber et al., 2004a) and 8 Mbp of a nonredundant genomic sequence (approximately 60% genome coverage; http://genomics.msu.edu/galdieria), we have conducted a comparative genomics pilot study to identify those genes of G. sulphuraria that might be crucial to its extraordinary metabolic flexibility (Barbier et al., 2005). To this end, we identified Galdieria sequences that did not match any of the C. merolae genes and that displayed similarity to genes of known function from other organisms. Although only 50% of the G. sulphuraria genome sequence had been finished at the time of the study, a number of important conclusions could be drawn: (1) Despite their evolutionary distance, the Cyanidiales have retained a high level of overall similarity in their genomes, (2) Galdieria genes contain more introns than those of Cyanidioschyzon, (3) only Galdieria is capable of metabolizing complex cell wall polysaccharides, (4) the lack of heterotrophy in Cyanidioschyzon is not accompanied by a strong reduction in its carbohydrate metabolism enzymatic make-up, and (5) the Galdieria genome encodes many more membrane transporters than that of Cyanidioschyzon (Barbier et al., 2005).

Lipid metabolism in G. sulphuraria is of particular interest because of its adaptation to extreme environments, in particular, to high temperature and low pH. Another point is the position of the Cyanidiales within the tree of life. G. sulphuraria is one of a few mesothermophilic eukaryotes currently under investigation with regard to adaptations of membrane lipid composition to high-temperature environments. Membranes of thermophilic bacteria are typically low in lipids with highly unsaturated fatty acids and archea have evolved etherlipids with long carbon chains that span the bilayer, thereby preventing bilayer separation or disintegration under high temperature regimes (Albers et al., 2000;Konings et al., 2002). Whether similar adaptations at the level of membrane lipid biosynthesis are also found in eukaryotic organisms is not yet clear. A preliminary lipid and genomic analysis has confirmed that G. sulphuraria contains the typical set of membrane lipids found in cyanobacteria and plants, however, the fatty acid substituents of the glycerolipids are more saturated than is typical for plastid lipids in seed plants (K. Awai and C. Benning, personal communication).

Seed plants such as A. thaliana contain a well-defined set of two galactolipid synthases that sequentially transfer galactosyl residues from UDP-Gal to the receptor molecule diacylglycerol to give rise to the monogalactosyl-or the digalactosyl-lipid, both main components of photosynthetic membranes in chloroplasts (Benning and Ohta, 2005). While cyanobacteria, relatives of the ancestor of the chloroplast in plants, harbor the same two lipids in their membranes, their galactosyltransferases are biochemically and evolutionally not related to the plant enzymes. Interestingly, the plastid genomes of the unicellular red algae Cyanidioschyzon merolae, Cyanidium caldarium, and Porphyra purpurea (Glö ckner et al., 2000;Ohta et al., 2003;Reith and Munholland, 1995) contain the cyanobacterial type digalactolipid synthase, while the nuclear genome encodes the plant type monogalactolipid synthase. More complex multicellular red algae such as Gracilaria tenuistipitata (Hagopian et al., 2004) appear not to encode the cyanobacterial-type digalactolipid synthase in their plastid genome. The nuclear and plastid genomes of the diatom Thalassiosira pseudonana (Armbrust et al., 2004) encode only plant type mono-and digalactolipid synthases. This is interesting because it is assumed that diatomean plastids are derived from the plastid of a unicellular red alga via secondary endosymbiosis (Bhattacharya et al., 2004).

As previously described and documented in Fig. 1, floridoside (2-O-D-glycerola-D-galactopyranoside) is an important compatible solute in G. sulphuraria. It is also the main carbon sink for photosynthesis of red algae in general (Kirst and Bisson, 1979). While biosynthesis of floridoside has been unraveled at the biochemical level (Kremer and Kirst, 1981;Srivastava, 1990, 1991), the corresponding enzymes are not known at the molecular level. The proposed pathway is mainly based on 14 C-feeding experiments: Glycerol 3-phosphate and floridoside phosphate have both been identified as direct precursors of floridoside. The first is derived from dihydroxyacetone phosphate via glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. In a subsequent step, glycerol 3-phosphate and UDP-galactose are condensed to floridoside phosphate by floridoside phosphate synthetase. Cleavage of the phosphate group generates floridoside as the final product.

As none of these enzymes has been purified and the corresponding genes are still unknown, a comparative approach of the genome projects of C. merolae and G. sulphuraria was undertaken by Barbier et al. (2005). This comparison yielded a number of candidate genes involved in floridoside biosynthesis--most of them with homology to enzymes involved in disaccharide synthesis (e.g., sucrose, trehalose) in higher plants. Selective cloning and expression of candidate genes can now be initiated to verify the role of enzymes in floridoside biosynthesis.

As previously outlined, the nitrogen metabolism of Cyanidiales has been studied at the enzyme activity level in quite some detail. With the availability of Cyanidiales genome sequences, we now can take a genomic perspective of nitrogen metabolism in these organisms. Clearly, the pathway of assimilation of ammonia into amino acids in the Cyanidiales must be diVerent from that in green plants: In green plants, both glutamate synthase and glutamine synthetase are encoded on the nuclear genome. Sequenced green plant nuclear genomes encode several glutamine synthetase isozymes (seven in Arabidopsis); one of these is plastid localized (GS2) and the others are cytosolic (GS1). Plastid-localized GS2 is the main isozyme involved in ammonia assimilation, as demonstrated by the phenotype of a barley mutant deficient in this enzyme (Blackwell et al., 1987). However, the Cyanidiales genomes encode only one isozyme of glutamine synthetase that lacks a predicted plastid-targeting sequence and that is, therefore, presumably localized in the cytosol, whereas, as previously outlined, glutamate synthase is encoded on the plastid genome in Cyanidiales. Therefore, both enzymes reside in diVerent cellular compartments. A similar situation (glutamate synthase activity exclusively in the plastid and the main glutamine synthetase activity in the cytosol) occurs in some gymnosperm seedlings (Weber and Flü gge, 2002). However, in this case (and in all other studied cases in green plants), the cytosol and the plastidic nitrogen and carbon metabolism are connected by a set of transporters in the plastid envelope membrane (two dicarboxylate transporters and one glutamate/glutamine transporter) that catalyzes the exchange of metabolic intermediates between plastid and cytosol (Linka and Weber, 2005;Weber, 2004;Weber and Flü gge, 2002;Weber et al., 2005). Although these transporters (i.e., dicarboxylate transporters) are essential for ammonia assimilation in green plants (Renné et al., 2003;Schneidereit et al., 2006;Tegeder and Weber, 2006;Weber, 2006;Weber et al., 2004b), related transporters cannot be detected in the sequenced Cyanidiales genomes (Barbier et al., 2005). Based on information contained in the Cyanidiales genome sequences and on what we know about ammonia assimilation in green plants, it is currently not possible to predict the pathway of ammonia assimilation in Cyanidiales. It will require metabolic flux analysis to unravel the pathway for the incorporation of inorganic nitrogen into organic nitrogen compounds in these organisms.

div.head: V. Conclusions and Perspectives
div.p: Although eukaryotic extremophiles have been studied for decades, only the advent of the ''omics'' era will enable comprehensive, systems-wide approaches to the exploration and understanding of the general strategies of adaptations. With few exceptions, previous studies of metabolic adaptation to extreme environments were limited to selective approaches, addressing only facets of the total. Research was mostly restricted to the analysis of already known mechanisms of adaptations in an increasing number of species. The discovery of novel strategies was more diYcult due to the lack of comprehensive profiling techniques and genomic information. It is expected that the onset of the omics era will provide a significant boost to the study and the understanding of the biology of extremophilic eukaryotes. It is only now that we have access to the first complete genome sequences of some of the fascinating eukaryotic extremophiles, and additional genomes will very likely become available soon. These genome sequences provide an overview of the potential adaptive and metabolic capacities of species and give insight into the evolution of adaptive stategies. In particular, comparative genomics of extremophilic and nonextremophilic species has already started yielding valuable information. However, the mere presence of genes does not provide information or evidence on their functionality or activity. That is where other levels of omics kick in--transcriptomics, metabolomics, and proteomics are essential tools to gain insight into the metabolic and control networks that distinguish extremophiles from mesophiles.

Only metabolomics provides information about the level of metabolites at a given time point and thus directly reflects the metabolic activity of extremophiles. By combining progress in the comprehensive analysis of metabolites, transcripts, and proteins in biological systems with the developments in quantitative and theoretical biology, it has now become possible to pursue systems-level approaches to understanding the biology of extremophiles.

figure.head: FIG. 1
figure.figDesc: GC-MS analysis of extracts of G. sulphuraria grown in the presence or absence of 1.25 M NaCl, respectively. The left panel shows the total ion current base peak chromatograms, with the major identified peaks indicated by a (proline), b (citrate), c (floridoside), and Ara (arabinose, standard). The mass spectra and chemical structures of compounds that accumulated in the 1.25 M NaCl culture are shown as insets in the right panel (a-c). The mass spectrum at the bottom of each inset represents the spectrum from the reference library, whereas the upper spectrum represents the spectrum from the actual extract. Large peaks that were also detectable in nonsample controls are marked by an X.
